page.title: Collecting practices of the Al-Thani Family

revision.text:
[[File:Museum of Islamic Art Doha.jpg|thumb|[[Museum of Islamic Art, Doha]]]] [[File:SheikhFaisalMuseumEntrance.jpg|thumb|Entrance to the [[Sheikh Faisal Bin Qassim Al Thani Museum]].]] {{Culture of Qatar}} The ruling family of [[Qatar]], the [[House of Thani]], is deeply involved in the field of art. For more than twenty years, some of its members have been accumulating numerous and precious pieces of artwork.
The project [[Qatar National Vision 2030]] promotes the creation of new schools, new universities and new museums.<ref name=autogenerated3>{{cite web|url=http://www.economist.com/node/21551443|title=Qatar’s culture queen|work=The Economist|accessdate=14 October 2015}}</ref> The Cultural development, characterized by new museums and exhibitions, is therefore closely linked to the political motive of building a “knowledge-based economy” in Qatar by 2030.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nyas.org/publications/ebriefings/Detail.aspx?cid=1e72282c-fdfb-48c1-a26b-866a2aa7ec6a|title=Building a Knowledge-based Economy in Qatar|publisher=|accessdate=14 October 2015}}</ref>
The journalist Barbara Pollack underlines the central role of the Al-Thani family while comparing Qatar's and [[Cultural policy in Abu Dhabi|Abu Dhabi’s cultural policies]]: "While Abu Dhabi is making a name for itself by building dramatic local satellites of the Louvres, the Guggenheim and the British Museum, Qatar's scheme of cultural nation building is much more homegrown, establishing its own museums rooted in the collections of its own royal family."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.artnet.com/magazineus/reviews/pollack/mathaf-arab-museum-of-modern-art-in-doha12-23-10.asp|title=Mathaf, Arab Museum of Modern Art opens in Doha in Qatar - artnet Magazine|date=23 December 2010|publisher=|accessdate=14 October 2015}}</ref>
== Collecting strategy of the Al-Thani family ==
=== Active members of the royal family ===
Several members of the Al-Thani family initially led Qatar's interest and involvement into the field of arts and continue to embody and shape the cultural policy of the country.<ref name="Al-Thani's involvement in the arts, Robert Kluijver">{{cite web|url=http://gulfartguide.com/essay/the-al-thanis-involvement-in-the-arts/|title=The Al Thani’s involvement in the arts|publisher=|accessdate=14 October 2015}}</ref> For William Lawrie, previously Head of International Modern Contemporary Arab and Iranian Art at [[Christie's]], “Qatar’s royal family are very much like modern-day equivalents of the [[Medicis]] in 16th-century Florence”.<ref name="An Emirate Filling Up With Artwork">{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/03/01/world/middleeast/in-qatar-artists-and-collectors-find-a-new-market.html?pagewanted=all&_r=0|title=An Emirate Filling Up With Artwork|publisher=New York Times|date=1 March 2012}}</ref>
* Sheikh Saud’s older brother, [[Hassan bin Mohamed bin Ali Al Thani]] owns one of the most extensive collections of modern Arab art in the world, estimated at 6,300 pieces.<ref name="Al-Thani's involvement in the arts, Robert Kluijver"/> While studying Art in Qatar University in the mid-1980s, he became deeply interested in 20th-century Arabic painting, and most particularly in Iraqi painters.<ref name="Christian Chesnot,Georges Malbrunot, ''Qatar: les clés du coffre-fort''">[Christian Chesnot,Georges Malbrunot, ''Qatar: les clés du coffre-fort'']</ref> Aware that art in general was "absent from Qatari life" at that time, he pursued the discovery of Arab artists.<ref name="Sajjil: A Century of Modern Art">[Sajjil: A Century of Modern Art], Nada Shabout, Wassan Al-khudhairi, Deena Chalabi.</ref> If Sheikh Hassan’s collection was primarily developed out of his personal interest in art and was not directed towards a specific audience, it now forms the core of the [[Mathaf]] museum. * [[Saud bin Muhammed Al Thani]], Qatari Emir Sheikh Hamad bin Khalifa al Thani's cousin and former president of Qatar's National Council for culture, Arts and Heritage possesses a large collection of traditional art pieces, such as manuscripts, carpets, scientific instruments and Mughai Jewellery.<ref name=autogenerated3 /> He largely contributes at establishing collections for five existing and planned museums: the Museum of Islamic Art, the National Library, the Natural History Museum, a photography museum and a traditional textiles and clothes museum.<ref name="Al-Thani's involvement in the arts, Robert Kluijver"/> * The emir's daughter [[Al-Mayassa bint Hamad bin Khalifa Al-Thani]] now embodies the involvement of Qatar's ruling family in art.<ref name=autogenerated1 /> As head of the [[Qatar Museums Authority]] (QMA), she is "arguably the most powerful woman in the art world today", according to the magazine ''Forbes'', which ranked her among the 100 most powerful women of the world in 2012.<ref name=autogenerated7 /> In 2011, ''[[Art+Auction]]'' magazine ranked her number one for the art world’s most influential people.<ref name="Qatari Emir's daughter named art world's most influential person">[http://dohanews.co/post/13672356727/qatari-emirs-daughter-named-art-worlds-most Qatari Emir's daughter named art world’s most influential person].</ref> According to Benjamin Genocchio, editor in chief of ''Art+Auction'', "Sheikha Al-Mayassa has the resources of an entire country at her disposal."<ref>[http://dohanews.co/post/13672356727/qatari-emirs-daughter-named-art-worlds-most Qatari Emir's daughter named art world's most influential person | Doha News<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
=== Qatari presence on the art market ===
Qatar is depicted as a new "market maker" on the art market.<ref name=autogenerated9>{{cite web|url=http://www.tradearabia.com/news/REAL_222998.html|title=Qatar a top player in art, museum markets|publisher=|accessdate=14 October 2015}}</ref> In 2011, [[The Art Newspaper]] revealed Qatar is the world’s biggest art buyer.<ref name=autogenerated5>[http://www.theartnewspaper.com/articles/Qatar-revealed-as-the-world%E2%80%99s-biggest-contemporary-art-buyer/24185 Qatar revealed as the world’s biggest contemporary art buyer - The Art Newspaper<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
Many commentators report a faultless strategy:<ref name=autogenerated4>[http://www.dohapress.com/portal/index.php/57-all-local-news/17856-qatar-a-top-player-in-art-museum-markets dohapress - Qatar a top player in art, museum markets<!-- Bot generated title -->] {{webarchive|url=https://archive.is/20130629011827/http://www.dohapress.com/portal/index.php/57-all-local-news/17856-qatar-a-top-player-in-art-museum-markets |date=2013-06-29 }}</ref> Qatar bid systematically for famous pieces of art. It is a pragmatic but visionary approach that led the country to establish itself as a main player of the world art market. Qatar is advised by high-skilled international experts.<ref name=autogenerated1>{{cite web|url=http://www.lepoint.fr/culture/offensive-du-qatar-sur-le-marche-de-l-art-26-09-2012-1510354_3.php|title=Offensive du Qatar sur le marché de l'art|author=Le Point, magazine|work=Le Point|accessdate=14 October 2015}}</ref> Thierry Ehrmann, president and founder of Artprice ("the world leader in art market information"<ref>{{cite web|url=http://web.artprice.com/en/|title=Art market, auction sales and artist’s prices and indices - Artprice, the world leader of art market information.|publisher=|accessdate=14 October 2015}}</ref>) asserts that Qatar has implemented an “outstanding war machine” to make of Doha a “world capital of art”.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://m.lesechos.fr/redirect_article.php?id=0202290809093|title=Les Echos.fr - Actualité à la Une - Les Echos|publisher=|accessdate=14 October 2015}}</ref> According to him: "Qatar does not take any risk, takes the best and is willing to pay whatever it takes."<ref name=autogenerated1 />
=== Large financial resources ===
One of the most striking facts about Qatar's presence on the art market is the massive financial resources involved. The royal family and Qatar's cultural institution are upscale subscribers to the databank on art prices and indices Artprice Group. A study conducted by Artprice and Organ Museum Research over the period 2000-2012 revealed that Qatar bid for art works with a margin of 40 to 45% above "market prices".<ref name=autogenerated4 /> Hence Forbes Magazine estimates that the annual budget for the sole Qatar Museum Authority is about $250 million.<ref name=autogenerated7>{{cite web|url=https://www.forbes.com/profile/sheikha-mayassa-al-thani/|title=Sheikha Mayassa Al Thani|author=Michael Kanellos|work=Forbes|accessdate=14 October 2015}}</ref>
The chief executive of the Fine Art Fund Group, an art investment management and consulting firm based in London, estimates that Qatari buyers make up to 25 percent of the Middle East's $11 billion art market.<ref name="An Emirate Filling Up With Artwork" />
== Al-Thani's art collection: overview == [[File:121 Snowy Owl.jpg|thumbnail|Audubon, Snowy Owl]] For more than twenty years, the Al-Thani family had been buying a large collection of art works, from traditional Islamic artifacts to famous pieces of modern and contemporary art
=== Antiques ===
Partly as a consequence of Sheikh Saud's significant interest into traditional art, the Al-Thani family possesses a wide collection of Islamic, Roman and Egyptian art and antiques, alongside a wide range of artifacts from all over the world.<ref name=autogenerated8>{{cite web|url=http://www.paulfrasercollectibles.com/News/ART-%26-PHOTOGRAPHY/2011-News-Archive/The-vast-and-spectacular-collections-of-Sheikh-Saud-al-Thani-of-Qatar/7076.page|title=The Vast And Spectacular Collections Of Sheikh Saud Al Thani Of Qatar|work=JustCollecting|accessdate=14 October 2015}}</ref> The collection includes:<ref name=autogenerated6>{{cite web|url=http://www.economist.com/node/17797006|title=A Smithsonian in the sand|work=The Economist|accessdate=14 October 2015}}</ref> * Artifacts (glass, carpets, astrolables) * Korans, manuscripts * Rare books, including a complete set of [[John James Audubon]]'s ''[[The Birds of America|Birds of America]]''<ref name="‘Birds Of America’ Sells for $8.8 Million">[http://www.artandantiquesmag.com/2009/02/call-of-the-wild/ Birds Of America’ Sells for $8.8 Million], Art&Antiques.</ref> * [[Persian miniature]]s * Fine jewellery * 18th-century French furniture * Natural history prints and specimens
=== Western art ===
Estimates show that the Al-Thani has spent at least $1 billion on Western painting and sculpture over the last twenty years.<ref name=autogenerated3 /> Sheikha Al-Mayassa is known for being particularly interested in the work of Western contemporary art's big names, such as [[Jeff Koons]], [[Takashi Murakami]], [[Damien Hirst]], [[Richard Serra]], [[Louise Bourgeois]] and [[Mark Rothko]] .<ref name=autogenerated9 />
The royal family of Qatar currently owns one painting of the series ''[[The Card Players]]'' by the French artist [[Paul Cézanne]]. [[File:Paul Cézanne 222.jpg|thumbnail|Paul Cézanne, ''The Card Players'']]
As a prominent buyer on the art market, the Al-Thani family has significantly expanded its modern art collection. The family owns notably: * Mark Rothko's painting ''[[White Center (Yellow, Pink and Lavender on Rose)]]'' * [[Francis Bacon]]'s ''Study from Innocent X'' * [[Damien Hirst]]'s ''Lullaby Spring''
=== Middle-Eastern and North African art === In addition to building collections of works by international artists, the Al-Thani family is committed to developing Arab contemporary art and supporting regional artists. The credit goes in the first place to Sheikh [[Hassan bin Mohamed bin Ali Al Thani]], who began buying Arab art in the mid-1980s while very little attention had been carried out on the region's artistic movements. In 1986, he started collaborating with the artist and art educator [[Yousef Ahmad]].
Hassan Al-Thani supported Iraqi artists after the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait and the first Gulf War. He owns an extensive collection of art pieces produced by two of the most well-known Iraqi artists [[Ismail Fatah Al Turk]] and [[Shakir Hassan Al Said]]. His collection of Iraqi art is known as the biggest in the world.<ref name="Art in Qatar: A Smithsonian in the sand">[http://www.economist.com/node/17797006 Art in Qatar: A Smithsonian in the sand], The Economist.</ref> According to Antonia Carver, Fair Director of Art Dubai, "News about Cézanne and Damien Hirst hits headlines, but it’s perhaps these more localized forms of patronage — such as Sheik Hassan’s care for Iraqi artists over several decades — that are particularly meaningful within the region."<ref name="An Emirate Filling Up With Artwork" />
The exhibition for the opening of [[Mathaf]] in December 2010 featured art pieces of several Arab artists, such as:<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lemonde.fr/culture/article/2010/12/18/doha-et-le-culot-de-l-art-moderne-arabe_1455368_3246.html|title=Doha et le culot de l'art moderne arabe|author=Harry Bellet – Doha, envoyé spécial|work=Le Monde.fr|accessdate=14 October 2015}}</ref> * French artists of Algerian origin Kader Attia and Zineb Sedira * Iraqi Adel Abidin * Palestinian Khalil Rabah * Moroccans Farid Belkahia and [[Mounir Fatmi]] * Egyptians Ahmed Nouar and [[Ghada Amer]] * Lebanese [[Walid Raad]]
=== Photography ===
Saud Al-Thani bought quite important photographs collections, notably 136 vintage photographs including pieces by [[Alfred Stieglitz]] and [[Man Ray]] in 2000 and a black and white photograph by [[Joseph-Philibert Girault de Prangey]] in 2003 for £565,250, which settled a new world record<ref name=autogenerated8 />
== Al-Thani's collection displayed: museums and exhibitions ==
With such wide art collections, Qatar proceeds for several years to build museums and to sponsor exhibition to host them. It makes part of Qatar's strategy to be acknowledged as a main worldwide actor.
=== Museums === [[File:Museum of Islamic arts SOP.jpg|thumb|[[Museum of Islamic Art, Doha]], designed by [[I.M. Pei]]]] ==== Qatar Museums Authority ====
One significant innovation has been the establishment of the [[Qatar Museums Authority]] in 2005, a government body that cooperates with the Culture Ministry but which is, according to ''The Economist'', "above all a family affair".<ref name=autogenerated3 /> Interviewed by the English newspaper, Sheikha Al-Mayassa asserts, "The QMA is very much my father’s baby. He wanted to create something to connect with the community, to create a cultural dialogue within society (…) we want the QMA to be a 'cultural instigator', a catalyst of arts projects worldwide."<ref name=autogenerated3 />
==== Museum of Islamic Art ====
Qatar's ambition to become the most important cultural destination of the Gulf’s area was made concrete in 2008 with the opening of the MIA, the [[Museum of Islamic Art, Doha|Museum of Islamic Art]].<ref name=autogenerated6 /> It was designed by [[I.M. Pei]], the Chinese-American architect that notably built the glass pyramid for [[the Louvre]] in Paris. It is considered to be one of the world’s great museums.<ref name="Museum of Islamic Art in Doha">[https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/art/art-features/9943622/Museum-of-Islamic-Art-in-Doha-Its-about-creating-an-audience-for-art.html Museum of Islamic Art in Doha].</ref>
* MIA Park The inauguration of the new public space was a key event of the year 2011. Developed by QMA and located on the grounds of the MIA, the park notably includes [[Richard Serra '7']]. The 80-foot-high sculpture is the American artist's first public work in the Middle East. The Emir Sheikh [[Hamad bin Khalifa Al Thani]] was present during the inaugural ceremony, along with 700 guests. During her speech, Sheikha Al Mayassa asserted that the new park will invite the citizens of Doha to interact with contemporary and other creative arts. At the same time, the new park will complement and enhance the Museum of Islamic Art designed by my father."<ref name="Official Unveiling of a new 80-Foot-High Sculpture by Richard Serra">[http://www.qma.com.qa/en/news/news-archive/389-official-unveiling-of-a-new-80-foot-high-sculpture-by-richard-serra Official Unveiling of a new 80-Foot-High Sculpture by Richard Serra] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130406173013/http://qma.com.qa/en/news/news-archive/389-official-unveiling-of-a-new-80-foot-high-sculpture-by-richard-serra |date=2013-04-06 }}, 15/12/2011.</ref>
==== Mathaf ====
The growing interest for Arab Modern art is symbolized by the opening of [[Mathaf]] in December 2010 (Mathaf is the Arabic word for museum). Based on a collection of paintings and other art pieces from the 1840s, this embryo project aims to give modern art a wider audience in the Arab world. “We are making Qatar the place to see, explore and discuss the creations of Arab artists of the modern era and of our own time” says Sheikha al-Mayassa al-Thani<ref name=autogenerated6 />
Its originator and most fervent defender, Sheikh [[Hassan bin Mohamed bin Ali Al Thani]] explains how the museum was aimed at filling a void in modern Arab art in Qatar: "Since the collection had increased its representation of periods and styles, I began planning to make it part of a specific project. At the time, I did not know of any museum of Arab art from the 19th century to today. As a painter and photographer — simply put, as an artist — I was passionate about modern and contemporary art and artistic movements in the Arab world. But only in Egypt could you find quality museums devoted to the history of Arab art and its different forms of expression. Otherwise there was almost nothing anywhere. So instead of continuing in the darkness, I decided to light a light".<ref name="Shining a Light: Sheikh Hassan Al-Thani on Qatar's First Museum of Modern Arab Art">[http://www.blouinartinfo.com/news/story/36609/shining-a-light-sheikh-hassan-al-thani-on-qatars-first-museum-of-modern-arab-art Shining a Light: Sheikh Hassan Al-Thani on Qatar's First Museum of Modern Arab Art].</ref>
==== National Museum of Qatar ====
One of the biggest projects of Qatar is the opening of the National Museum that was scheduled to open in 2016. As for the MIA, Qatar succeeded in involving the well-known French architect [[Jean Nouvel]] on the project.
====Sheikh Faisal Bin Qassim Museum==== The [[Sheikh Faisal Bin Qassim Al Thani Museum]] was opened in 1998 and currently showcases over 15,000 artifacts that were collected by Faisal Bin Qassim Al Thani over a span of several years.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2014-03-25/hidden-qatar-billionaire-al-thani-seen-with-hotel-empire|title=Hidden Qatar Billionaire Al-Thani Seen With Hotel Empire|publisher=Bloomberg|author=Devon Pendleton|date=25 March 2014|accessdate=25 December 2015}}</ref>
=== Art events ===
Besides largely contributing to the construction of new museums, Al-Thani Family is involved in a wide range of art events.
* Murakami Ego and Qatar Japan 2012
In 2010, Qatar funded the exhibition of the Japanese artist Takashi Murakami, known as [[Murakami-Ego]] and shown at the [[Palace of Versailles]] in 2010.<ref name="Murakami Versailles">[http://www.chateauversailles.fr/index.php?option=com_cdvfiche&view=cdvchapitre&template=blank&idr=4028A278-9490-AAA2-23BD-969CF32A1C61&idc=BC34C6D8-D61E-9849-D601-77977BC22A0B Murakami Versailles].</ref> The exhibition was later shown in Doha in 2012.<ref name=autogenerated5 /> The Museum of Islamic Art was initially proposed, yet the Japanese artist found the space not large enough. A temporary hall was built instead, known as the Al Riwaq exhibition space, located near the MIA.<ref name="Art in the Middle East Dubai & Doha, Sima Familant">[http://www.simafamilant.com/dubai-doha Art in the Middle East Dubai & Doha, Sima Familant], 10/05/2012.</ref> It is the first exhibition displayed by Murakami in the Middle East. Murakami-Ego was the launching event of Qatar-Japan 2012, an initiative aimed at reinforcing the diplomatic relations between the two countries through a series of cultural and sporting activities.<ref name="Murakami’s First Exhibition in the Middle East">[http://qatarjapan2012.com/online/en/details/109 Murakami’s First Exhibition in the Middle East]</ref>
* Louise Bourgeois and ''[[Maman (sculpture)|Maman]]''
From January to June 2012, [[Qatar Museums Authority]] organized the exhibition "Conscious and Unconscious", gathering about 30 works of art created by [[Louise Bourgeois]] between 1947 and 2009.<ref name="Louise Bourgeois: Conscious and Unconscious">[http://www.qma.com.qa/en/news/news-archive/409-louise-bourgeois-conscious-and-unconscious Louise Bourgeois: Conscious and Unconscious] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130408092408/http://qma.com.qa/en/news/news-archive/409-louise-bourgeois-conscious-and-unconscious |date=2013-04-08 }}, QMA.</ref> The centrepiece of the exhibition is the famous 9-meter-high bronze spider sculpture ''[[Maman (sculpture)|Maman]]''. QMA's chairperson, Sheikha Al-Mayassa, commented on the importance of the sculpture to Qatar: "Louise Bourgeois' ''Maman'' is a true icon of 20th Century art, an artwork that has captured the attention of millions around the world. We are proud to present this magnificent sculpture at the [[Qatar National Convention Centre]]. Through displaying various forms of art in public spaces we aim to inspire local talent and to establish an organic connection between art and the local community.".<ref name="QMA unveils new spider sculpture">[http://www.qma.com.qa/en/news/news-archive/346-qatar-museums-authority-unveils-new-spider-sculpture-at-qatar-national-convention-center QMA unveils new spider sculpture] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130406173728/http://qma.com.qa/en/news/news-archive/346-qatar-museums-authority-unveils-new-spider-sculpture-at-qatar-national-convention-center |date=2013-04-06 }}.</ref> The sculpture will stay permanently in Doha.
* Photography Contest: Al-Thani award for Photography
The Photography Competition, created in 2001, is amply sponsored by [[Saud bin Muhammed Al Thani]]. It has greatly expanded over the last 12 years, opened to the Gulf Region in 2003, to the Arab World in 2005. It became an international competition in 2006.<ref name="Thousands of entries for annual Al-Thani award for Photography">[http://thepeninsulaqatar.com/cover-plus/213212-thousands-of-entries-for-annual-al-thani-award-for-photography.html Thousands of entries for annual Al-Thani award for Photography], The Peninsula Qatar, 05/11/2012.</ref>
== Controversies ==
The active participation of the ruling family in the art market has invited some controversy and criticism concerning transaction opacity and the public/private nature of financial resources involved.
=== Opacity and secrecy ===
Al Thani family formally refuses to confirm or deny the rumours circulating over the art acquisitions of these past years. It is therefore particularly hard to assess whether these acquisitions are purely private or done on behalf of the State.<ref name=autogenerated3 />
=== Saud al Thani under house arrest in 2005 ===
In 2005, Saud Bin Mohammed Al-Thani was sued for not fulfilling a payment of $20 million for ancient Greek coins.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2226278/Royal-sheikh-spent-1billion-art-collection-accused-leaving-extraordinary-trail-unpaid-debt-worlds-auction-houses.html|title=Royal sheikh who spent more than £1billion on his art collection is accused of leaving 'extraordinary trail' of unpaid debt around world's top auction houses - Daily Mail Online|work=Mail Online|accessdate=14 October 2015}}</ref> This event rekindled the concerns about his huge spending on art artifacts, estimated at $2.5 billion over eight years.<ref name=autogenerated8 />
==See also== * [[Hassan bin Mohamed bin Ali Al Thani]] * [[Al-Mayassa bint Hamad bin Khalifa Al-Thani]] * [[Mathaf]] * [[Qatar Museums Authority]]
== Sources == * [http://www.economist.com/node/21551443 "Art and the Middle East: Qatar's culture Queen", ''The Economist'', 31 March 2012] * [http://www.theartnewspaper.com/articles/Qatar-revealed-as-the-world%E2%80%99s-biggest-contemporary-art-buyer/24185 Georgina Adam and Charlotte Burns, "Qatar revealed as the world’s biggest contemporary art buyer", ''The Art Newspaper'', 7 July 2011] * Robert Kluijver, [http://gulfartguide.com/essay/qatar/ "Introduction to the Gulf Art World"] * Christian Chesnot, Georges Malbrunot, Qatar: les clés du coffre-fort, Michel Lafont, March 2013
== References == {{Reflist|30em}}

{{Infobox artwork | image_file=File:Cow wallpaper - Andy Warhol.jpg | title=Cow Wallpaper [Pink on Yellow] | artist=[[Andy Warhol]] | year=1966 | medium=Screen print on wallpaper | accession= | dimensions = {{convert|46|x|28|in|cm}} | city=[[North Shore (Pittsburgh)|North Shore, Pittsburgh]] | museum=[[The Andy Warhol Museum]] }} [[Andy Warhol]]'s '''''Cow Wallpaper''''' was the first in a series of wallpaper designs he created from the 1960s to the 1980s. According to Warhol, the inspiration for the cow image came from art dealer [[Ivan Karp]]:
Another time he said, 'Why don't you paint some cows, they're so wonderfully pastoral and such a durable image in the history of the arts.' (Ivan talked like this.) I don't know how 'pastoral' he expected me to make them, but when he saw the huge cow heads — bright pink on a bright yellow background — that I was going to have made into rolls of wallpaper, he was shocked. But after a moment he exploded with: 'They're ''super''-pastoral! They're ridiculous! They're blazingly bright and vulgar!' I mean, he loved those cows and for my next show we papered all the walls in the gallery with them.{{cite book |last1=Warhol |first1=Andy |last2=Hackett|first2=Pat|title=POPism: The Warhol 60s |date=1980|publisher=Harcourt Brace Jovanovich|location=New York|isbn=9780151730957|page=18|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=xtI3AQAAIAAJ}}
The show Warhol refers to is his April, 1966 show at the [[Leo_Castelli#Leo_Castelli_Gallery|Leo Castelli Gallery]], which consisted only of ''Cow Wallpaper'' in one room, and a second room with Warhol's silver helium-filled ''Clouds''.{{cite web|title=Andy Warhol|url=https://www.castelligallery.com/artists/Warhol/warhol.html|website=Castelli Gallery|accessdate=31 October 2017}} The historian and critic [[Barbara Rose]] interpreted ''Cow Wallpaper'' as a commentary on the nature of art collecting and the character of the institutions where art is displayed. In a review of Warhol's 1971 retrospective show at the [[Whitney Museum of American Art|Whitney]], she observed that cows are a common subject of [[Genre painting|genre paintings]] that people display in their homes, and that the wallpaper made the Whitney look like "a boutique." She continued, "Of course the museum has been a boutique for a long time, and people have been treating paintings like wallpaper even longer. But Andy spells it out with his usual cruel clarity."{{cite news|last1=Rose|first1=Barbara|title=In Andy Warhol's Aluminum Foil, We Have All Been Reflected|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ij-_4jJ4oj8C&printsec=frontcover#v=onepage&q&f=false|work=New York Magazine|date=31 May 1971|page=55|issn=0028-7369|language=en}} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External Links== *[https://www.castelligallery.com/artists/Warhol/warhol.html Pictures of 1966 show at Leo Castelli Gallery (scroll down to April, 1966)] *[http://www.artecapital.net/arq_des-129-o-efeito-breuer-parte-2 Picture of 1971 show at Whitney] *[https://www.metmuseum.org/art/collection/search/499047 Version of ''Cow Wallpaper'' exhibited at the Whitney, in the collection of the Metropolitan Museum of Art] {{Andy Warhol}} [[Category:Art by Andy Warhol]] [[Category:Fictional cattle]] [[Category:American art]] {{art-stub}}

{{Infobox NRHP | name = New Century Club | image = Delaware Children's Theatre 01.jpg | caption = The front of the theatre | coordinates = {{coord|39|45|6|N|75|33|22|W|format=dms|display=inline,title}} | location = 1014 Delaware Avenue, [[Wilmington, Delaware|Wilmington]], [[Delaware]] | locmapin = Delaware#USA | area = Cool Springs neighborhood | built = 1893 | architect = Minerva Parker Nicholas | architecture = [[Colonial Revival architecture|Colonial revival]] | added = 1983-06-16 | refnum = 83001336<ref>{{cite web|url=http://nrhp.focus.nps.gov/natregsearchresult.do?fullresult=true&recordid=77|title=New Century Club|last=|first=|date=1983-06-16|publisher=[[National Park Service]]|accessdate=2010-01-31}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref> | visitation_num = | visitation_year = }}
The '''Delaware Children's Theatre''' ('''DCT''') is a community theatre in [[Wilmington, Delaware]], United States. The theatre company occupies the historic '''New Century Club''' building.
==Theatre company== Originally named the Children's Repertory Theatre of Wilmington, the organization began in 1973 with their first production of ''[[Pinocchio]]''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dechildrenstheatre.org/aboutdct/history.html|title=History |last=|first=|date=|publisher=Delaware Children's Theatre|accessdate=2010-02-01}}</ref> The organization relies on volunteers for all acting and nearly all support positions as a community theater. To cover operating expenses, DCT sells tickets and receives state support through the Delaware Division of the Arts.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.artsdel.org/grants/grantawards2010.pdf|title=Delaware Division of the Arts Grant Awards: FY2010|last=|first=|year=2010|publisher=Delaware Division of the Arts|accessdate=2010-02-01}}</ref>
[[Tony Award]] winner [[John Gallagher, Jr.]] initially played Tom Sawyer as a child actor at the theatre before going on to [[Broadway theatre|Broadway]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://blogs.delawareonline.com/pulpculture/2009/09/29/leaving-the-nest-for-birdie/|title=Leaving the nest for 'Birdie' |last=Ruston|first=Muriel|date=2009-09-29|publisher=[[The News Journal]]|accessdate=2010-02-01}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.filmbug.com/db/293337|title=John Gallagher, Jr.|last=|first=|date=|publisher=Film Bug|accessdate=2010-02-01}}</ref>
==New Century Club==<!--This section is linked from other articles--> The Theatre occupies the historic New Century Club building. The organization constructed the building in 1893 and occupied it until 1975. The Delaware Dinner Theatre and Delaware Ballet Company then used the building until 1982 when DCT moved in.<ref>{{cite web|url={{NRHP url|id=83001336}}|title=National Register of Historic Places Inventory-Nomination Form|last=Briggs|first=Robert|date=January 1983|publisher=[[National Park Service]]|accessdate=2010-01-31}}</ref>
[[Minerva Parker Nichols]] of Philadelphia, an early female architect, designed the [[Colonial Revival architecture|Colonial Revival]] building with [[Palladian window]]s and a [[gambrel]] roof. While serving partly as a clubhouse, it also held a theatre which was used for traveling shows as well as civic speakers, including future president [[Woodrow Wilson]] and birth control advocate [[Margaret Sanger]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=2294&dat=19540124&id=tswmAAAAIBAJ&sjid=bgIGAAAAIBAJ&pg=1366,563399|title=New Century Club Celebrates Sixty-Fifth Anniversary|last=Ruston|first=Muriel|date=1954-01-24|publisher=Wilmington Sunday Star|accessdate=2010-01-31|at=Section 3, Page 7}}</ref>
The structure is listed as on the [[National Register of Historic Places]] and recognized as being an active place for the women's rights movement.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nps.gov/wori/parkmgmt/upload/Appendix%20E.pdf|title=Properties Associated with the Women’s Rights Movement|last=|first=|date=|publisher=[[National Park Service]]|accessdate=2010-01-31, page 72}}</ref> The New Century Club was a [[Progressivism in the United States|progressive]] upper class women's group dedicated to social improvement and charity as well as [[Women's suffrage in the United States|women's suffrage]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.eric.ed.gov/ERICWebPortal/custom/portlets/recordDetails/detailmini.jsp?_nfpb=true&_&ERICExtSearch_SearchValue_0=EJ843424&ERICExtSearch_SearchType_0=no&accno=EJ843424|title=Women's Clubs as Educative Agencies: Wilmington, Delaware New Century Club, 1889-1920|last=Taggart|first=Robert|year=2006|publisher=American [[History of education|Educational History]] Journal|accessdate=2010-01-31}}</ref> Notable members of the Club included Emily P. Bissell, a Red Cross campaigner against tuberculosis who has a state hospital named after her, and Emalea Pusey Warner, who successfully campaigned for public vocational education and has a local elementary school named in her honor.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dhss.delaware.gov/dph/ltc/epbh.html=enabled|title=Emily P. Bissell Hospital (EPBH)|last=|first=|date=|publisher=[[Delaware]] Division of Public Health|accessdate=2010-01-31}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://redclay.schoolnet.com/outreach/epwes/mrsw/=enabled|title=About Warner|last=|first=|date=|publisher=[[Red Clay Consolidated School District]]|accessdate=2010-01-31}}{{dead link|date=September 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> Other New Century women's clubs formed nearby in [[National Register of Historic Places listings in Kent County, Delaware|Milford]] and [[Newark, Delaware]], as well as in Kennett Square, West Chester, and Chester, Pennsylvania.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lib.udel.edu/ud/spec/findaids/newcent1.htm|title=Archive of the New Century Club of Newark, Delaware|last=Wellner|first=Anita A.|date=1893–1996|publisher=[[University of Delaware]] Library|accessdate=2010-01-31}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.oldchesterpa.com/clubs_century_july_1942.htm|title=New Century Club|last=Bullock|first=John A.|date=July 1942|publisher=Old Chester|accessdate=2010-01-31}}</ref>
==See also== {{Portal|Delaware}} * [[New Century Club (Utica, New York)]] * [[Grand Opera House (Wilmington, Delaware)]] * [[National Register of Historic Places listings in Wilmington, Delaware]]
